definition: the lord of Lu (who declined to employ Confucius)
(bound form) crass/stupid/rude/(used to represent the sounds of "ru", "lu" etc in loanwords)
surname Lu/Lu, ancient state of China 魯國|鲁国[Lu3 guo2]/Lu, short name for Shandong 山東|山东[Shan1 dong1]
monarch/lord/gentleman/ruler

sentences.english: The duke treated the bird as a distinguished guest. In consequence, he tortured the bird to death.
sentences.chinese: 鲁君以上宾的待遇养鸟，结果把鸟儿给弄死了。

definition: Lu, vassal state at the time of the Zhou Dynasty 周朝|周朝[Zhou1 chao2], located in the southwest of present-day Shandong 山東|山东[Shan1 dong1], birthplace of Confucius
Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏子, hero of book 晏子春秋
Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏婴, hero of book 晏子春秋
King Min of Qi (reigned 323-284 BC)
Duke Huan of Qi (reigned 685-643 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
my late father/my ancestors/the late emperor
Qi state of Western Zhou and the Warring states (1122-265 BC), centered in Shandong
Duke Wen of Jin (697-628 BC, reigned 636-628 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Guan Zhong (-645 BC), famous politician of Qi 齊國|齐国 of Spring and Autumn period/known as Guangzi 管子
a restricted view through a bamboo tube
Lord Menchang of Qi, Chancellor of Qi and of Wei during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
King Xuan of Qi (reigned 342-324 BC)
King Zhuang of Chu (reigned 613-591 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Zi Gong or Duanmu Ci 端木賜|端木赐[Duan1 mu4 Ci4] (520 BC-), disciple of Confucius
Zi Chan (?-522 BC), statesman and philosopher during the Spring and Autumn period
Duke Mu of Qin, the first substantial king of Qin (ruled 659-621 BC), sometimes considered one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
surname Cheng/Zhou Dynasty (1046-256 BCE) vassal state
